summary: This is a Memorandum Opinion & Order by Judge Alison J. Nathan in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell. The order resolves a dispute over the terms of a protective order, ultimately adopting the Government's proposed language. It restricts Maxwell from publicly referencing alleged victims or witnesses except those who have publicly identified themselves in this litigation, and denies Maxwell's request to restrict potential Government witnesses from using discovery materials for purposes other than trial preparation.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, seeking specific language in a protective order regarding public references to alleged victims/witnesses and restrictions on Government witnesses.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge who authored the opinion and order, ruling on the protective order dispute between the Government and the defense.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as a central figure in the case; the protective order dispute involves individuals who have made public statements relating to him or Maxwell.

connections.description: The document references litigation and public statements relating to both Maxwell and Epstein, indicating their legal and alleged operational connection.
Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal case and issued this ruling on the protective order requested by Maxwell's defense.

events.title: Court Issues Protective Order Ruling
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issues a Memorandum Opinion & Order adopting the Government's proposed protective order in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell.

keyFacts: The court denied Ghislaine Maxwell's request for a broad exception to publicly reference alleged victims or witnesses who had made any public statement 'relating to' her or Jeffrey Epstein, finding the request too broad and a risk to privacy protections.
The court adopted the Government's narrower language, allowing Maxwell to publicly reference only individuals who have spoken by name on the record in *this* specific criminal case.

The court denied Maxwell's unprecedented request to restrict potential Government witnesses and their counsel from using discovery materials for any purpose other than preparing for this criminal trial.
The ruling emphasizes the strong interest in protecting the privacy of alleged victims and witnesses, even if they have made past public statements.
The document is a formal court order (Docket No. 37) that resolves the motion for a protective order (Docket No. 29).
